Module title: Choosing the right dog for your lifestyle
Brief Description: This module helps you choose a dog whose energy, size, temperament, and needs match your lifestyle. A good match reduces future behaviour problems and stress for both you and the dog.
Detailed Description: In this module, you will learn how to honestly assess your own lifestyle, schedule, energy level, and living situation, and compare that to what different types of dogs require. You will consider factors like breed tendencies, exercise needs, grooming demands, size, noise levels, and typical health issues. By understanding these elements before bringing a dog home, you greatly reduce the risk of frustration, rehoming, or behavioural struggles and lay the groundwork for a successful long-term partnership.
Brief Step 1: List your daily routine and activity level.
Brief Step 2: Read guidance on different dog types and their needs.
Brief Step 3: Compare your lifestyle to several dog profiles.
Brief Step 4: Narrow down realistic options that truly fit.
Brief Step 5: Decide which type of dog you can fairly meet the needs of.
Detailed Step 1: Start by writing down a realistic picture of your life: work hours, social life, physical abilities, financial capacity, and home environment (apartment vs rural property, shared spaces, landlord restrictions, etc.).
Detailed Step 2: Learn how different breeds and types of dogs vary in exercise needs, mental stimulation, grooming, typical health issues, and vocal tendencies.
Detailed Step 3: Compare these breed profiles directly against your lifestyle list – ask not “What dog do I want?” but “What dog would thrive with the life I can provide every day?”
Detailed Step 4: Rule out options that clearly do not fit (for example, very high-drive working breeds in very low-activity homes) and focus on breeds or mixes whose needs you can reliably meet.
Detailed Step 5: Use this clarity to guide adoption or purchase decisions, knowing that a good match will make training easier, reduce problem behaviours, and improve the dog’s overall welfare and happiness.

Brief Description: This module gets your whole family on the same page before the dog arrives. Clear roles, rules, and expectations prevent confusion and help your dog adapt faster.
Detailed Description: Here you will learn how to prepare everyone in the household for the arrival of a dog. The module explains why consistency is essential: if one person allows jumping or feeding from the table while others do not, the dog becomes confused and behaviours become harder to change. You will cover safety rules for children, how to interact calmly, and how to avoid overwhelming the dog. By setting family agreements early, you create a predictable environment that supports training and reduces stress for both the dog and the humans.
Brief Step 2: Discuss how to greet and handle the dog calmly.
Brief Step 3: Agree on household rules (e.g., no feeding from the table).
Brief Step 5: Write the agreed rules somewhere visible.
Detailed Step 1: Schedule a short family discussion before the dog comes home and explain that everyone’s behaviour will shape how the dog feels and acts.
Detailed Step 2: Talk through calm greeting rules (no shouting, grabbing, or crowding the dog) and why this helps the dog feel safe and prevents fear or overexcitement.
Detailed Step 3: Agree on non-negotiable rules such as whether the dog is allowed on furniture, whether anyone can feed from the table, and how jumping or mouthing will be handled so the dog receives the same message from everyone.
Detailed Step 4: Assign age-appropriate responsibilities to each family member (for example, one person handles feeding, one does short play or training sessions, another supervises toileting trips) so the dog builds positive associations with multiple people.
Detailed Step 5: Write down the agreed rules and responsibilities, post them somewhere visible, and review them again right before the dog arrives so that the household feels prepared and united, making training more effective from day one.

Brief Description: This module lists the essential supplies you need before bringing your dog home. Being prepared reduces stress and sets you up for smooth training from day one.
Detailed Description: This module gives you a clear, structured checklist of items that support safety, comfort, training, and enrichment. It covers feeding equipment, bedding, crates or pens, leashes and harnesses, ID tags, cleaning supplies, grooming tools, and interactive toys. For each category, you will understand why it matters and how it will be used in your dog’s daily life and training. Having everything ready in advance allows you to focus on bonding and calm, predictable routines rather than last-minute panic shopping.
Brief Step 1: Read through the full supply checklist.
Brief Step 4: Set up feeding, sleeping, and toileting areas with these supplies.
Brief Step 5: Double-check you have basic training and safety tools ready.
Detailed Step 1: Go through the checklist slowly and make sure you understand each category: food and water bowls, appropriate food, a crate or pen, dog bed, leash, harness, ID tag, poo bags, cleaning products, grooming tools, and a variety of safe chew and enrichment toys.
Detailed Step 2: Mark off anything you already have at home and note what needs to be purchased so you can make one planned shopping trip rather than multiple rushed visits.
Detailed Step 3: Choose items that are appropriate for your dog’s size, age, and breed (for example, chew strength for toys or correct harness fit).
Detailed Step 4: Set up your dog’s main areas using these supplies: decide where they will eat, sleep, rest, and toilet, and place items consistently so the dog can easily learn these locations.
Detailed Step 5: Confirm that your training basics (treat pouch, treats, toys, long line, and similar tools) are ready before arrival so you can immediately start rewarding good behaviour and building positive habits from the first moment your dog is in your home.

Brief Description: This module helps you arrange your home to support safety, calmness, and good habits. Safe spaces and management tools make early training easier and prevent many problems.
Detailed Description: In this module, you will learn how to structure your home environment to help your dog feel secure and to protect them from accidents. You will explore how to use baby gates, pens, crates, and closed doors to manage where the dog can go, and how to create quiet rest areas away from heavy foot traffic. You will also cover removing common hazards like exposed wires, toxic plants, or chewable valuables. A well-planned setup allows you to prevent rehearsals of unwanted behaviours (like counter-surfing or chewing furniture) and creates a calm, predictable space where your dog can relax and learn.
Brief Step 1: Identify where the dog will eat, sleep, and rest.
Brief Step 2: Decide which areas are off-limits and set up gates or barriers.
Brief Step 3: Remove hazards such as cables, toxic plants, and small objects.
Brief Step 4: Create at least one quiet, safe resting zone.
Brief Step 5: Walk through your home from a “curious dog” perspective and adjust as needed.
Detailed Step 1: Walk through your home and select specific zones for resting, playing, training, and toileting so your dog does not have to guess what each space is for.
Detailed Step 2: Use gates, exercise pens, or closed doors to limit access to risky or overwhelming areas (such as kitchens with hot appliances, cluttered rooms, or open staircases) during the early adjustment period.
Detailed Step 3: Remove or secure common hazards including electrical cords, small objects that can be swallowed, unsecured rubbish bins, toxic plants, medications, and human food that could harm your dog.
Detailed Step 4: Set up a dedicated quiet space (often with a crate or bed) where your dog can retreat to rest undisturbed; this teaches them that relaxation is safe and helps prevent clinginess and over-arousal.
Detailed Step 5: Finally, walk around at dog-eye level, imagining what a curious animal might chew, knock over, or investigate. Make any last adjustments so that your dog’s first experiences exploring your home are safe, calm, and easy to supervise, which in turn makes training much smoother.

Module title: The first 24 hours: what to expect
Ideal Stage of Life: Before getting a dog (review again on arrival day)
Brief Description: This module prepares you for your dog’s first day in their new home. Knowing what to expect helps you stay calm, set the right tone, and avoid overwhelming your dog.
Detailed Description: Here you will learn what your dog is likely experiencing physically and emotionally in their first 24 hours with you. The module covers common reactions such as stress, excitement, withdrawal, or over-tiredness and explains how your responses can either ease or increase their anxiety. You will be guided through simple routines for feeding, toileting, rest, and gentle interaction, as well as what to avoid (like crowds or constant handling). By following this plan, you help your dog feel safe, begin to understand the new routine, and build the first layer of trust that all future training will rely on.
Brief Step 1: Read this before your dog comes home.
Brief Step 2: Plan a calm, simple first day.
Brief Step 3: Introduce toilet area, water, and resting place.
Brief Step 5: Allow plenty of rest and avoid overcrowding or big events.
Detailed Step 1: Before bringing your dog home, read through this module so you know what a realistic first day looks like and do not create pressure to “do everything” immediately.
Detailed Step 2: When you arrive, take your dog calmly to their toilet area first, then show them where their water, food, and resting spot are located; avoid long tours of the whole house at once.
Detailed Step 3: Keep greetings soft and controlled; limit the number of people interacting at a time and avoid loud voices, hugging, or crowding, which can be intimidating or over-arousing.
Detailed Step 4: Follow a simple structure for the day: short periods of gentle interaction, toilet breaks, and quiet rest in their safe space, rather than constant stimulation or long play sessions.
Detailed Step 5: Recognize that your dog may pant, pace, whine, or seem shut down at times—these can be normal adjustment responses. By staying calm, sticking to a predictable routine, and giving them space when needed, you help them begin to feel secure, which will make all future behaviour and training work much easier.

Module title: Establishing routines: feeding, potty, and sleep
Brief Description: This module teaches you how to create predictable routines for feeding, toileting, and sleep. Consistency helps puppies and new dogs feel secure and dramatically reduces accidents and stress.
Detailed Description: This module explains why routine provides structure and emotional safety. Dogs thrive on predictability—regular mealtimes help with digestion and easier toilet training, scheduled naps prevent overtired behaviour, and consistent potty breaks reduce accidents. You will learn what a realistic first-week schedule looks like, how often puppies need to toilet, how to prevent overtiredness, and how structured routines reduce anxiety as your dog adapts to their new environment.
Brief Step 5: Adjust gently as the dog settles.
Detailed Step 1: Link each meal, nap, and play session to a toilet break by taking your dog outside immediately afterwards, helping them learn where to go.
Detailed Step 2: Create a basic sleep routine by providing several quiet nap periods throughout the day in a safe resting area so your dog does not become overtired and fractious.
Detailed Step 3: Follow this schedule as consistently as possible for the first week so your dog begins to predict what happens next, which reduces anxiety.
Detailed Step 4: Observe how your dog responds and adjust timing gradually while keeping the underlying structure the same, using your schedule as a living document rather than a rigid rule.

Brief Description: This module helps you understand what to expect during your dog’s first nights and how to support them through anxiety or restlessness.
Detailed Description: The first few nights can be challenging because your dog is adapting to a new environment away from their littermates or previous home. This module teaches you how to create comfort, reduce crying, and encourage healthy sleep habits. You will learn about sleep setups, calming strategies, whether to crate nearby, how to handle crying without reinforcing anxiety, and how to gradually transition the dog to independent sleeping over time.
Brief Step 2: Keep the dog close by at first.
Brief Step 4: Take out for toilet breaks as needed.
Brief Step 5: Gradually increase independence over several nights.
Detailed Step 1: Choose a safe nighttime setup such as a crate or pen placed near your bed so your dog is not suddenly isolated, which can trigger panic.
Detailed Step 2: Provide soft bedding, a safe chew, and gentle background noise (like a fan or white noise) to create a soothing sleep environment.
Detailed Step 3: When your dog cries, calmly assess whether they may need a toilet break, and if so, take them out quietly without turning it into playtime.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid over-comforting with constant talking or picking up, as this can accidentally teach that crying always brings attention; instead, aim for calm, brief reassurance.
Detailed Step 5: As your dog becomes more confident over the first several nights, gradually move the crate or pen toward its long-term location and lengthen the periods between check-ins, building healthy independent sleep habits.

Module title: Introducing family members and other pets
Brief Description: This module explains how to introduce your new dog to family members and resident pets safely and calmly.
Detailed Description: Improper introductions can create fear or tension that affects relationships long-term. This module teaches owners how to introduce dogs to adults, children, and other pets in a controlled way. You will learn how to read body language, manage excitement, prevent overwhelming greetings, and use barriers or leashes when appropriate. It also covers how to introduce dogs to cats, older dogs, or anxious animals using structured and gradual methods.
Brief Step 2: Introduce one person or pet at a time.
Brief Step 3: Use leashes or barriers when needed.
Brief Step 5: End interactions while they are still positive.
Detailed Step 1: Start with short, one-on-one introductions instead of bringing many people to greet the dog at once.
Detailed Step 2: Coach family members, especially children, to move slowly, avoid hugging or leaning over the dog, and let the dog approach them first.
Detailed Step 3: For other pets, use baby gates, pens, or leashes to allow sniffing and observation without forced close contact, giving both animals room to retreat.
Detailed Step 4: Watch each animal for signs of stress (stiffness, turning away, lip licking, growling, hiding) and respond by increasing distance and lowering intensity.
Detailed Step 5: Keep early interactions brief and end them before anyone becomes overwhelmed, gradually increasing time together as all animals show relaxed, calm body language.

Module title: First vet visit and early health care
Brief Description: This module prepares you for your dog’s first vet visit and covers early health needs like vaccines and parasite prevention.
Detailed Description: A dog’s first vet check is crucial for vaccinations, parasite control, and establishing a health baseline. This module explains what to bring, what the vet will check, how to reduce fear, and how to advocate for your puppy or rescue. You will also learn how to introduce cooperative care early so your dog has more positive experiences at the vet and is easier to handle throughout life.
Brief Step 4: Keep the clinic visit calm and positive.
Brief Step 5: Follow the vet’s recommended health plan.
Detailed Step 1: Book the first vet appointment within the first few days of bringing your dog home, especially if vaccinations or health checks are due.
Detailed Step 2: Bring all available paperwork (adoption forms, previous medical records) and plenty of soft, high-value treats.
Detailed Step 3: In the days before the visit, briefly practice touching your dog’s paws, ears, and mouth in exchange for treats to build comfort with handling.
Detailed Step 4: At the clinic, use a calm voice, reward your dog frequently, and advocate for gentle, minimal restraint where possible.
Detailed Step 5: Discuss vaccination schedules, parasite prevention, microchipping, nutrition, and any concerns with your vet, then follow the agreed plan and note follow-up dates in your calendar.

Brief Description: This module highlights the most common early mistakes owners make and how to avoid them.
Detailed Description: Many early problems come from misunderstandings rather than intentional errors. This module explains mistakes like overstimulation, giving too much freedom too soon, inconsistent rules, allowing unwanted behaviours to develop, reinforcing anxiety or whining, and relying on punishment. By becoming aware of these patterns, owners can prevent problems instead of fighting them later, making the entire training journey smoother and kinder for the dog.
Brief Step 2: Notice which ones you might be doing.
Brief Step 5: Revisit this module regularly during the first month.
Detailed Step 1: Carefully read a list of typical early mistakes such as letting the dog roam unsupervised, picking them up every time they cry, or allowing jumping because they are “still a puppy.”
Detailed Step 2: Reflect honestly on which of these might already be happening in your home and how they could affect your dog’s long-term behaviour.
Detailed Step 3: Make concrete changes to your routines: use more management (gates and pens), add structure to rest and play, and stop unintentionally rewarding behaviours you do not want.
Detailed Step 4: Share these insights with all family members so everyone responds to the dog in the same way, making learning clear and predictable.
Detailed Step 5: Revisit this module regularly in the first month as habits form, using it as a self-check tool to keep your training and handling on track.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to begin forming a secure, trusting bond with your new dog.
Detailed Description: Trust is the foundation of all training and behaviour. This module explains how to build trust through calm interactions, predictable routines, gentle handling, and meeting the dog’s basic needs without pressure. You will learn how to avoid overwhelming your dog, how to encourage curiosity, and why trust-building sets the stage for future training success.
Brief Step 1: Keep your behaviour calm and predictable.
Brief Step 2: Let your dog choose to approach you.
Brief Step 5: Build confidence with small, positive experiences.
Detailed Step 1: Focus on moving slowly and speaking softly around your new dog, especially in the first days, so they begin to associate you with safety and calmness.
Detailed Step 2: Allow your dog to come to you rather than chasing or grabbing them; reward these voluntary approaches with gentle praise and treats.
Detailed Step 3: Maintain predictable feeding, toileting, and rest routines so your dog can start to anticipate what will happen next, which reduces anxiety.
Detailed Step 4: Limit exposure to chaotic environments, loud gatherings, or constant handling until your dog shows clear signs of comfort and curiosity.
Detailed Step 5: Provide small, successful experiences—such as exploring one new room, meeting one calm person, or practising one easy training game—which gradually builds your dog’s confidence and deepens their trust in you as a reliable, kind caretaker.

Category title: Training Introduction: Setting the Owner Up for Success
Brief Description: This module explains the basic science of how dogs learn, so owners understand why training works the way it does.
Detailed Description: In this module, you will learn that dogs learn through associations and consequences in the moment. You will discover how reinforcement strengthens behaviours, why timing and consistency matter so much, and how a dog’s emotional state affects their ability to learn. We also cover key concepts like thresholds and arousal, and the difference between shaping, capturing, and luring behaviours. With this foundation, training stops feeling like guesswork and becomes a clear, fair communication system between you and your dog.
Brief Step 1: Read the overview of learning theory.
Brief Step 3: Understand the role of emotions and arousal.
Brief Step 5: Reflect on how your own actions influence behaviour.
Detailed Step 1: Start by reading about the basic learning principles: dogs repeat behaviours that are rewarded and avoid behaviours that lead to unpleasant outcomes or no benefit.
Detailed Step 2: Learn that timing is critical—dogs connect rewards or consequences with what happened in the last one or two seconds, not what happened minutes earlier.
Detailed Step 3: Explore how your dog’s emotional state (calm, excited, fearful) can either open the door to learning or shut it down entirely; a relaxed, curious dog learns much faster than a frightened or frantic one.
Detailed Step 4: Study the three main ways of teaching new behaviours: capturing (rewarding when the dog does it naturally), shaping (rewarding tiny steps toward the final behaviour), and luring (using food or a target to guide the dog into position), and note when each is most useful.
Detailed Step 5: Reflect on your daily interactions and recognise that your dog is always learning from you—every treat, every bit of attention, and every situation you manage or ignore teaches your dog what works in your shared world.

Category title: Training Introduction: Setting the Owner Up for Success
Brief Description: This module teaches you how to use marker words or a clicker so your dog clearly understands what they did right.
Detailed Description: Marker training is a simple but powerful communication system that tells your dog the exact moment they earned a reward. In this module, you will learn how to introduce a reward marker (such as “Yes” or a clicker sound), a duration marker (such as “Good”), and a non-reward marker (such as “Try again”). You will see how clear markers make training faster and less frustrating for both of you, and how tone and timing affect your dog’s understanding.
Brief Step 1: Choose your reward marker word or clicker.
Brief Step 2: Charge the marker by pairing it with rewards.
Brief Step 3: Practise using it at the correct moment.
Brief Step 5: Introduce a gentle “Try again” as a non-reward marker.
Detailed Step 1: Decide whether you will use a clicker, a short word like “Yes,” or both as your main reward marker and make sure everyone in the home uses the same one.
Detailed Step 2: Begin using the marker in simple training games (like rewarding eye contact or hand touches), focusing on saying it at the exact moment your dog does the desired behaviour.
Detailed Step 3: Introduce a calm, drawn-out “Good” to let your dog know they are on the right track while they hold a position, such as staying on a mat or in a sit.
Detailed Step 4: Add a gentle non-reward marker like “Try again” when your dog offers the wrong behaviour, immediately followed by another chance to respond, so they get clear feedback without fear or harshness.

Category title: Training Introduction: Setting the Owner Up for Success
Brief Description: This module helps you understand what truly motivates your dog and how to use rewards effectively in training.
Detailed Description: Different dogs are motivated by different things. In this module, you will learn how to identify what your dog loves most—food, toys, play, sniffing, or social contact—and how to use those rewards strategically. You will discover how to vary reward types and value, how to avoid overusing food without a plan, and how to transition from continuous reinforcement to more variable schedules once behaviours are strong. Understanding motivation makes training more fun and far more effective.
Brief Step 2: Create a reward hierarchy (low to high value).
Brief Step 3: Pair high-value rewards with difficult tasks.
Brief Step 4: Use everyday life rewards when possible.
Brief Step 5: Gradually vary reward frequency for well-learned skills.
Detailed Step 1: Experiment with several reward types—soft treats, kibble, tug toys, balls, praise, and access to sniffing or play—and notice which ones your dog gets most excited about.
Detailed Step 2: Build a simple reward hierarchy by ranking these from “everyday” to “jackpot” so you can match reward value to task difficulty.
Detailed Step 3: Use your highest-value rewards for challenging skills or distracting environments, and lower-value rewards for easy, well-practised behaviours.
Detailed Step 4: Look for opportunities to use real-life rewards such as being released to run, greet a friend, or sniff a tree, so your dog learns that listening to you makes good things happen in the world.
Detailed Step 5: Once a behaviour is reliable, shift from rewarding every correct response to rewarding most responses with occasional jackpots, which keeps motivation high while preventing dependence on constant food.

Category title: Training Introduction: Setting the Owner Up for Success
Brief Description: This module explains how to choose and use basic training tools and how to set up ideal learning environments.
Detailed Description: The right equipment and environment make training safer, clearer, and less stressful. In this module, you will learn about leashes, harnesses, long lines, treat pouches, and enrichment items, as well as how to choose options appropriate for your dog’s size and temperament. You will also learn how to set up low-distraction training areas, structure short sessions, and gradually introduce more challenging environments as your dog’s skills grow.
Brief Step 1: Choose appropriate leash, harness, and long line.
Brief Step 2: Set up a low-distraction training space.
Brief Step 3: Prepare treats, toys, and a treat pouch.
Brief Step 4: Gradually move to slightly more distracting environments.
Detailed Step 1: Select a sturdy, comfortable leash and a well-fitted harness or flat collar that gives you control without causing pain or fear; avoid tools that rely on intimidation or discomfort.
Detailed Step 2: Obtain a long line for safe practice of recall and distance work in open spaces, particularly for young or newly adopted dogs who are not yet reliable off leash.
Detailed Step 3: Set up an initial training area in a quiet part of your home or yard where your dog is less likely to be distracted by other animals, people, or noises.
Detailed Step 4: Gather soft treats, a treat pouch, and a couple of favourite toys before each session so you can reward quickly and keep momentum going.

Category title: Training Introduction: Setting the Owner Up for Success
Brief Description: This module teaches you how to gradually make behaviours more reliable in real-life situations.
Detailed Description: Training does not stop once your dog knows a cue at home. In this module, you will learn how to “proof” behaviours by gradually adding distraction, distance, and duration in a structured way. You will understand how to use a three-level environment system (easy, medium, hard), how to change only one difficulty factor at a time, and how to spot signs that you have progressed too quickly. Proper proofing turns basic skills into reliable real-life tools you can depend on.
Brief Step 2: Add one difficulty factor at a time.
Brief Step 3: Step back if your dog struggles.
Brief Step 4: Repeat until reliable in many contexts.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by practising new behaviours in very easy environments, such as a quiet room at home, where your dog is calm and focused.
Detailed Step 2: Once your dog responds reliably, increase the difficulty slightly by adding either a small distraction, a bit more distance, or a longer duration—but only change one factor at a time.
Detailed Step 3: Watch your dog’s performance and body language; if they seem confused, stressed, or start failing frequently, return to an easier level and rebuild confidence.
Detailed Step 4: Gradually work through multiple environments and situations, revisiting easier levels whenever needed, so that your dog learns that the cue means the same thing no matter where you are or what is happening around you.

Category title: Training Introduction: Setting the Owner Up for Success
Brief Description: This module helps owners build sustainable training habits that fit into daily life.
Detailed Description: Even the best training plan fails if it is not used consistently. This module teaches you how to weave short sessions into your everyday routine, how to avoid burnout, and how to keep training enjoyable for both you and your dog. You will learn about micro-sessions, stacking training onto existing habits (like mealtimes and walks), using checklists or logs, and recognising when you or your dog need a break. Building a training habit turns progress into a natural part of life rather than a chore.
Brief Step 5: Adjust when you or your dog feel tired or stuck.
Detailed Step 1: Choose one or two behaviours to focus on in each micro-session rather than trying to work on everything at once.
Detailed Step 2: Keep a simple log or checklist, marking what you practised and how it went so you can see progress over time and spot patterns or sticking points.
Detailed Step 3: Make sessions enjoyable by ending on an easy win, using good rewards, and stopping before either of you becomes frustrated or bored.
Detailed Step 4: If you notice that you or your dog are feeling overwhelmed, reduce the difficulty, shorten sessions, or take a planned break, then restart with fresh energy and clearer goals.

Module title: The Role of Exercise in Behavior
Brief Description: This module explains how physical and mental exercise affect your dog’s behaviour, mood, and overall wellbeing.
Detailed Description: Dogs require both physical and mental exercise to stay balanced and well‑behaved. In this module, you'll learn how unmet exercise needs often lead to problem behaviours like barking, chewing, jumping, or restlessness. You’ll also explore how appropriate exercise supports calmness, improves sleep, and enhances your dog’s ability to learn. The module explains the difference between overstimulation and healthy exertion, helping owners find the right balance for their dog’s age and breed.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by reading how inadequate exercise commonly leads to behavioural issues such as excessive barking, digging, pacing, and inability to settle, especially in young or high‑drive dogs.
Detailed Step 2: Review recommendations for your dog’s age, breed, and energy level to form a realistic understanding of their physical and mental needs.
Detailed Step 3: Observe and record any signs of under‑exercise such as restlessness, destructive chewing, or difficulty relaxing.
Detailed Step 4: Learn how too much or poorly timed exercise can lead to overstimulation or hyper‑arousal, such as after long high‑intensity play sessions.
Detailed Step 5: Begin shaping a daily routine that includes both physical and mental outlets to create a calmer, more focused dog.

Brief Description: This module teaches you the different forms of exercise and how to choose the right mix for your dog.
Detailed Description: Dogs benefit from a combination of physical activities (like walks, runs, and free play) and mental stimulation (like scent games, problem‑solving, and training sessions). This module explains each exercise type, the benefits and risks, and how often they should be included. You will learn how structured walks differ from casual sniff walks, when running is appropriate, how to use fetch safely, and how mental exercise can tire a dog more effectively than physical exertion alone.
Detailed Step 1: Read the overview of each exercise type: casual sniff walks, structured heel walks, play sessions, tug, fetch, swimming, jogging, supervised off‑leash time, and mental enrichment.
Detailed Step 2: Consider your dog's age and physical development—young puppies need very gentle exercise and controlled activities.
Detailed Step 3: Plan daily mental stimulation using training games, puzzle toys, or scent activities, which reduce boredom and increase calmness.
Detailed Step 4: Learn safe fetch and tug guidelines to avoid repetitive strain or over‑arousal.
Detailed Step 5: Build a balanced daily routine that includes a mix of physical exercise, decompression walks, and mentally challenging tasks.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to exercise their dog safely and avoid injury, fear, or overstimulation.
Detailed Description: Healthy exercise depends on understanding your dog’s age, growth stage, breed, and environment. This module explains the risks of over‑exercise in puppies, how to manage weather extremes, signs of heat stress, and how to prevent strain injuries. You'll also learn safe warm‑ups and cool‑downs, how to recognise fatigue, and why some breeds require modified exercise plans. Proper safety reduces long‑term injury and teaches dogs to enjoy exercise without becoming overstimulated or anxious.
Detailed Step 1: Read recommendations for age‑appropriate exercise, especially how puppies' joints and growth plates need gentle, controlled activity.
Detailed Step 2: Learn how to modify exercise based on heat, humidity, or cold—dogs overheat faster than humans.
Detailed Step 3: Practice spotting early signs of fatigue or overheating: slowing down, panting heavily, lagging behind, or seeking shade.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid excessive repetitive activities such as constant ball throwing, sharp turns, or jumping for young dogs.
Detailed Step 5: Implement simple warm‑ups (slow walking, gentle movement) and cool‑downs (gradual slowing, sniffing breaks) to reduce injuries.

Brief Description: This module helps owners design a balanced daily exercise plan tailored to their dog’s breed, age, and temperament.
Detailed Description: Different dogs have different needs, and structured plans prevent overstimulation or under‑stimulation. This module walks you through building a weekly routine that includes physical exercise, mental enrichment, rest days, and controlled exposure to new environments. You’ll learn how to adjust intensity, rotate activities, and build sustainable habits that support behaviour, training progress, and overall wellbeing.
Detailed Step 1: Start by researching general exercise needs for your dog's breed or type, then adjust for your dog’s individual temperament and energy level.
Detailed Step 2: Select a mix of physical activities (walks, play sessions, swimming) and mental enrichment (training, puzzles, scent games).
Detailed Step 3: Build a weekly plan with predictable structure, cycling between higher‑energy and lower‑energy days.
Detailed Step 4: Include at least one rest day per week where activity is lighter and focused on calmness and recovery.
Detailed Step 5: Monitor your dog’s behaviour—if they seem overly excitable, destructive, or restless, increase mental stimulation; if they seem fatigued or sore, reduce intensity.

Brief Description: This module explains why crate training supports safety, independence, and stress reduction.
Detailed Description: Crate training provides dogs with a secure den-like environment where they can rest comfortably and safely. This module explains how a crate prevents accidents, supports house training, reduces destructive chewing, and helps dogs learn independence. You’ll learn why a crate is not a punishment tool, how it benefits both puppies and adult dogs, and how it contributes to calmer behaviour in the home and during travel.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by understanding the crate as a safe resting space rather than a discipline tool, emphasising its role in house training and preventing unwanted behaviour.
Detailed Step 2: Choose a crate large enough for your dog to stand, turn, and lie comfortably but not overly spacious.
Detailed Step 3: Start by simply allowing your dog to explore the crate voluntarily with the door open.
Detailed Step 4: Pair the crate with rewards such as treats, chews, and meals to create positive associations.
Detailed Step 5: Avoid using the crate for punishment or extended confinement beyond recommended durations to preserve trust and comfort.

Brief Description: This module guides you through the step-by-step process of teaching your dog to love the crate.
Detailed Description: This module breaks crate introduction into small, achievable stages so your dog builds a positive emotional connection to the crate. You’ll learn how to introduce the crate without pressure, how to shape voluntary entry, how to add duration, and how to close the door gradually. The module teaches gentle progressions that prevent fear, crying, and crate avoidance.
Detailed Step 1: Start by placing the crate in a quiet but social area and leaving the door open so your dog can explore freely.
Detailed Step 2: Toss treats inside or place a soft blanket to encourage your dog to step in without being forced.
Detailed Step 3: Begin feeding meals inside the crate to build a strong positive association.
Detailed Step 4: Once comfortable, close the door for a few seconds while your dog is eating, opening it before they finish.
Detailed Step 5: Gradually extend the duration with calm behaviours, adding chews or enrichment and keeping each step easy enough to prevent distress.

Module title: Teaching your dog to be comfortable alone
Brief Description: This module teaches how to build healthy independence and prevent separation anxiety.
Detailed Description: Many dogs struggle with being left alone if not taught gradually. This module explains how to build independence through short separations, safe confinement, calm departures, and predictable routines. Owners learn how to prevent dependency, how to handle crying, and how to increase alone-time slowly without triggering anxiety.
Detailed Step 1: Start with micro‑separations such as stepping out of sight for a few seconds and returning before your dog becomes distressed.
Detailed Step 2: Keep departures calm and neutral to avoid signalling to your dog that something stressful is happening.
Detailed Step 3: Return only when your dog is calm to reinforce emotional stability rather than frantic behaviour.
Detailed Step 4: Gradually extend separation duration, using crates, pens, or safe rooms to create security.
Detailed Step 5: Implement predictable routines around alone-time so your dog knows what to expect, reducing anxiety and building resilience.

Brief Description: This module helps owners identify, manage, and reduce early signs of separation anxiety.
Detailed Description: Separation anxiety can develop in puppies and adult dogs when alone-time is rushed or inconsistent. This module teaches how to identify early warning signs, structure training to build independence, use enrichment to reduce anxiety, and avoid common mistakes that intensify clinginess. You’ll also learn when professional help is necessary, and how early intervention prevents long-term behavioural issues.
Detailed Step 1: Learn the early signs of separation distress such as pacing, whining, barking, drooling, or following you constantly.
Detailed Step 2: Begin structured independence training using controlled short absences and gradual desensitisation.
Detailed Step 3: Avoid returning to your dog while they are distressed, as this can reinforce panic and dependency.
Detailed Step 4: Use safe enrichment such as chews, snuffle mats, or puzzle feeders to keep your dog engaged during short alone periods.
Detailed Step 5: Contact a trainer or behaviourist if your dog continues to panic despite consistent training, as professional guidance ensures safe and humane progress.

Brief Description: This module teaches the fundamental principles of safe, structured socialisation for puppies and adult dogs.
Detailed Description: Socialisation is the process of introducing a dog to new experiences in a positive, gradual way. This module explains how early exposure shapes confidence, prevents fear-based behaviours, and supports long-term behavioural stability. Owners learn how to create safe, low-pressure experiences that build curiosity instead of fear. This applies equally to older rescue dogs who may need gentle re-socialisation.
Detailed Step 1: Read the definition of socialisation and understand why early exposure helps prevent fear, reactivity, and anxiety later in life.
Detailed Step 2: Begin by choosing low-intensity environments and gentle experiences that match your dog’s confidence level.
Detailed Step 3: Pair each new sight, sound, or object with treats or praise to create a positive emotional response.
Detailed Step 4: Watch your dog closely for signs of stress and adjust distance or intensity accordingly.
Detailed Step 5: Keep exposure sessions short, ending on a positive note to build long-term confidence.

Brief Description: This module explains the puppy socialisation period and how timing affects learning and behaviour.
Detailed Description: Puppies have a sensitive developmental period—typically between 3 and 16 weeks—when they are most open to new experiences. This module teaches owners how to safely expose puppies to essential stimuli during this window while avoiding overwhelm. It also explains how adult dogs can still learn through a modified socialisation process, even if they missed early exposure.
Detailed Step 1: Study the timeline of the critical socialisation period and understand why early positive exposure is crucial for preventing fear and aggression later.
Detailed Step 2: Identify essential experiences such as sounds, textures, people, animals, handling, car rides, and environments.
Detailed Step 3: Choose safe, controlled exposures tailored to your puppy’s vaccine status and confidence.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid overwhelming or flooding experiences, which can cause fear rather than confidence.
Detailed Step 5: Track exposures weekly to ensure variety and balanced learning.

Module title: Introducing new people, dogs, and environments
Brief Description: This module shows how to safely introduce a dog to new people, friendly dogs, and new environments.
Detailed Description: Many behavioural issues stem from poor or overwhelming early introductions. This module teaches structured approaches for meeting new people, greeting friendly dogs, and exploring new environments without fear. It covers managing excitement, reading body language, and avoiding unsafe dog interactions. Owners learn how to build positive associations and avoid common mistakes that slow socialisation progress.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by choosing calm, dog-friendly individuals for early people introductions and avoid crowds or overly energetic greetings.
Detailed Step 2: Introduce your dog to friendly, stable dogs who communicate clearly and avoid any dog showing rude or intense behaviour.
Detailed Step 3: Use distance as a safety tool—give your dog space to observe before approaching.
Detailed Step 4: Reward any voluntary curiosity such as glancing, sniffing, or stepping toward a new person or environment.
Detailed Step 5: Keep outings short and gradually increase duration as confidence builds.

Module title: Positive exposure to sounds, objects, and handling
Brief Description: This module teaches how to expose your dog to everyday sounds, objects, and physical handling in a safe, positive way.
Detailed Description: Exposure to sounds, movement, and gentle handling teaches dogs to stay relaxed during real-world situations. This module covers vacuum cleaners, doorbells, traffic, grooming tools, children’s toys, and more. It also teaches cooperative care handling such as touching paws, teeth, ears, and collar. The goal is to build calm familiarity rather than fear or avoidance.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by selecting everyday sounds and objects such as traffic noise, kitchen appliances, wheelchairs, bikes, and grooming tools.
Detailed Step 2: Play sounds at very low volume or introduce objects from a safe distance to prevent fear.
Detailed Step 3: Pair each exposure with treats and praise to build positive emotional associations.
Detailed Step 4: Practise gentle cooperative handling by touching paws, ears, mouth, collar, and tail while rewarding calm behaviour.
Detailed Step 5: Increase volume, duration, or proximity slowly as confidence grows.

Module title: Socialising with children and household pets
Brief Description: This module teaches safe interactions with children and other pets in the home.
Detailed Description: Dogs and children often misunderstand each other. This module teaches owners how to supervise interactions, teach children appropriate behaviour, and prevent accidental fear or aggression. It also explains how to introduce dogs to cats, small animals, and older or anxious pets using structured, low-pressure methods. Owners learn how to protect everyone’s safety while building positive long-term relationships.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by teaching children how to interact respectfully: no grabbing, hugging, or crowding the dog.
Detailed Step 2: Supervise every interaction between dogs and children or pets, stepping in early if excitement rises.
Detailed Step 3: Use gates or pens to create safe observation opportunities before close contact.
Detailed Step 4: Reward calm behaviour from both the dog and children to reinforce positive interactions.
Detailed Step 5: Keep sessions brief and end them immediately if either the dog or child shows signs of stress.

Module title: Name recognition and attention to owner
Brief Description: This module teaches your dog to recognise their name and check in with you reliably.
Detailed Description: Name recognition is one of the most important foundation skills. It teaches your dog that their name means “look at me” rather than “come here” or “stop.” This module explains how to build strong focus using reward-based association, how to avoid overusing the name, and how to develop reliable check-ins even around distractions. A dog who responds to their name is easier to train, easier to manage, and safer in everyday environments.
Detailed Step 1: Begin indoors in a quiet space. Say your dog’s name once—never repeat it.
Detailed Step 2: The moment your dog looks toward you, mark with “Yes!” and reward.
Detailed Step 3: Keep sessions short and fun to build a positive emotional connection to their name.
Detailed Step 4: Practise in different rooms and during calm moments to build reliability.
Detailed Step 5: Gradually introduce mild distractions, rewarding check-ins to strengthen focus in real-world environments.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to use markers correctly during real training sessions.
Detailed Description: Markers (“Yes,” clicker, or other signals) help dogs understand exactly which behaviour is being rewarded. This module expands on practical timing, reward delivery, and how to combine markers with cues and shaping. Owners learn how to avoid common mistakes such as marking too late or mixing markers unintentionally, ensuring fast, clear learning.
Detailed Step 1: Pick a clear, short marker such as “Yes!” that all family members will use.
Detailed Step 2: Practise timing by marking simple behaviours like sits or head turns to build precision.
Detailed Step 3: Use the marker during real training sessions to highlight correct actions.
Detailed Step 4: Maintain consistency across all handlers to avoid confusing the dog.

Brief Description: This module teaches your dog how to regulate excitement, frustration, and arousal.
Detailed Description: Impulse control is essential for preventing jumping, mouthing, barking, and general chaos. This module teaches foundational exercises such as settling, default calmness, offering patience, waiting for permission, and managing emotional arousal. Owners learn how to reduce overstimulation, use structured training games, and help their dog choose calm behaviour without relying on punishment.
Detailed Step 1: Start by rewarding naturally calm behaviours such as sitting, lying down, or looking away.
Detailed Step 2: Use patience games like waiting for eye contact before tossing a treat.
Detailed Step 3: Teach simple boundaries such as waiting at doorways or sitting before meals.
Detailed Step 4: Practise in quiet environments before adding mild distractions to avoid overwhelming the dog.

Brief Description: This module teaches dogs to accept grooming, touching, and health handling calmly.
Detailed Description: Handling skills make vet visits, grooming, and everyday care stress-free. This module covers cooperative care basics including touching paws, ears, teeth, and tail; brushing; nail prep; and collar handling. Owners learn how to desensitise sensitive dogs, build trust, and use rewards to make physical handling safe and comfortable for both dog and human.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by touching your dog’s paws, ears, and shoulders lightly while giving treats for calm behaviour.
Detailed Step 2: Keep sessions very short and always stop before your dog becomes uncomfortable.
Detailed Step 3: Gradually increase the length of touch and introduce brief lifts, holds, or gentle brushing.
Detailed Step 4: Slowly introduce grooming tools such as brushes, nail files, or clippers from a distance before using them.
Detailed Step 5: Practise daily to build familiarity and prevent handling-related fear from developing.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to reduce puppy nipping and develop safe, gentle bite inhibition.
Detailed Description: Puppies explore the world with their mouths, but without guidance this becomes painful nipping. This module explains why puppies nip, how to teach gentle mouthing, how to redirect biting, and how to build frustration tolerance. You’ll learn the difference between normal puppy behaviour and red flags, plus how to handle teething, overstimulation, and play biting safely.
Detailed Step 1: Redirect nipping by immediately offering a toy or chew any time your puppy goes for hands, feet, or clothing.
Detailed Step 2: Mark and reward moments when your puppy licks or mouths gently to reinforce bite inhibition.
Detailed Step 3: If biting increases, end the interaction briefly to teach that roughness stops play.
Detailed Step 4: Provide multiple chew outlets such as teething toys, frozen chews, and safe long-lasting treats.
Detailed Step 5: Practise daily calm handling so your puppy learns not to use teeth when touched or restrained.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to manage teething and prevent destructive chewing.
Detailed Description: Chewing is a normal developmental behaviour, especially during teething. This module explains how to prevent furniture damage, provide appropriate chew toys, supervise effectively, and manage the environment. You’ll learn how to redirect chewing, crate or confine when needed, and recognise signs of boredom or anxiety-related chewing.
Detailed Step 1: Offer a variety of safe chew items matched to your puppy’s teething needs—soft chews for early stages and firmer ones for older puppies.
Detailed Step 2: Supervise closely to prevent access to unsafe items like cords or furniture.
Detailed Step 3: Redirect by calmly giving your puppy an appropriate chew when they make a wrong choice.
Detailed Step 4: Rotate toys regularly to maintain novelty and reduce boredom.
Detailed Step 5: Use crates, pens, or baby gates when you cannot supervise to prevent destructive habits from forming.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to prevent and reduce jumping behaviour.
Detailed Description: Jumping is a common attention-seeking behaviour. This module teaches how to reinforce calm greetings, manage excitement, use prevention strategies, and avoid accidentally rewarding jumping. Owners learn how to coach visitors, teach alternative behaviours, and build reliable impulse control during greetings.
Detailed Step 1: Withhold attention—no touching, talking, or eye contact—whenever your puppy jumps.
Detailed Step 2: Reward and praise immediately when all four paws are on the floor.
Detailed Step 3: Teach a default sit for greetings to give your puppy a clear job.
Detailed Step 4: Instruct visitors to follow the same rules, avoiding accidental reinforcement.
Detailed Step 5: Practise structured greeting sessions with family members to build consistency.

Brief Description: This module helps owners understand and manage barking behaviour appropriately.
Detailed Description: Barking can stem from boredom, fear, excitement, or frustration. This module teaches owners how to identify the underlying cause and apply the right strategy—calmness training, redirecting focus, environmental changes, or increased enrichment. You’ll learn when to intervene, when to ignore, and how to reduce triggers in the environment.
Detailed Step 1: Determine whether the barking is alerting, attention-seeking, boredom-driven, fear-based, or frustration-related.
Detailed Step 2: Modify the environment by blocking visual triggers, adding rest, or reducing overstimulation.
Detailed Step 3: Redirect barking into an alternative behaviour such as going to a mat or performing a cue.
Detailed Step 4: Mark and reward quiet moments, increasing duration over time.
Detailed Step 5: Avoid yelling or punishment, which increases arousal and can worsen barking.

Brief Description: This module teaches effective toilet training and how to prevent marking issues.
Detailed Description: Potty training requires structure, supervision, and predictable routines. This module covers scheduling, crate use, accident prevention, appropriate reinforcement, and how to manage marking in adolescent dogs. Owners learn how to build reliable toilet habits and how to troubleshoot common setbacks.
Detailed Step 1: Establish a consistent feeding routine to predict your puppy’s toileting needs.
Detailed Step 2: Reward outdoor toileting immediately with praise and treats.
Detailed Step 3: Supervise indoors using leashes, pens, or gates to prevent silent accidents.
Detailed Step 4: Clean accidents with an enzymatic cleaner and avoid punishment, as it causes fear without teaching the correct behaviour.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to reduce hyperactivity and arousal spikes in puppies.
Detailed Description: Overexcitement can lead to zoomies, barking, nipping, jumping, and difficulty focusing. This module teaches how to use calmness protocols, structured play, enrichment, and rest balance. Owners learn to recognise early signs of overstimulation and redirect energy before it escalates.
Detailed Step 1: Reduce overstimulating triggers like rough play, chaos, or long periods without rest.
Detailed Step 2: Reward calm behaviours and reinforce settling on a mat.
Detailed Step 3: Use short, structured play sessions with predictable rules.
Detailed Step 4: Increase mental enrichment such as sniffing games, puzzles, or short training sessions.
Detailed Step 5: Ensure your puppy has adequate nap time to prevent overtiredness, which often presents as hyperactivity.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to read basic and subtle canine body language signals.
Detailed Description: Understanding dog body language helps prevent misunderstandings, fear, and conflict. This module explains signals such as posture, tail movement, facial expressions, ear positions, and tension. Owners learn how dogs communicate comfort, discomfort, playfulness, fear, stress, and aggression—often long before vocalisations occur. Recognising these early cues helps create safer interactions and more confident training.
Detailed Step 1: Study key areas of canine communication: eyes, ears, mouth, tail, posture, and movement.
Detailed Step 2: Observe what relaxed body language looks like—soft eyes, loose muscles, neutral tail, and fluid movement.
Detailed Step 3: Learn stress signals such as lip licking, yawning, turning away, freezing, and whale eye.
Detailed Step 4: Watch for context-based cues like weight shifts, lowered body posture, or stiffening, which often predict escalation.
Detailed Step 5: Practise observing your dog during training, play, and rest to build fluency reading their signals.

Brief Description: This module explains common dog communication signals and what emotional states they represent.
Detailed Description: Dogs use a combination of visual, auditory, and movement-based signals to communicate their feelings. This module breaks down common signals—like tail wag types, vocalisations, play bows, freezes, and avoidance behaviours—and teaches owners how to interpret these accurately. Understanding meaning behind signals prevents misinterpretation and helps owners respond appropriately.
Detailed Step 1: Review classic play signals such as the play bow, loose movement, and soft expression.
Detailed Step 2: Learn fear and insecurity signals like tucked tail, crouching, trembling, or avoiding eye contact.
Detailed Step 3: Study frustration cues including whining, pawing, pacing, and barking when blocked.
Detailed Step 4: Understand that dogs communicate using clusters of signals rather than individual cues.
Detailed Step 5: Practise identifying signals in everyday interactions to strengthen your observation skills.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to recognise early signs of stress and the calming signals dogs use to defuse tension.
Detailed Description: Dogs often show subtle calming signals to avoid conflict and regulate their emotions. These include yawning, sniffing, blinking, turning away, and slow movements. This module helps owners recognise when their dog is overwhelmed, how to reduce environmental pressure, and how to support calmer emotional states. Early recognition prevents escalation into fear or reactivity.
Detailed Step 1: Learn common calming signals such as head turns, soft blinking, slow movements, yawning, and ground sniffing.
Detailed Step 2: Identify what triggers stress—new environments, fast movements, loud noises, or unfamiliar dogs.
Detailed Step 3: Reduce intensity by increasing distance, lowering volume, or stopping interaction.
Detailed Step 4: Give your dog space and time to process instead of pushing them forward.
Detailed Step 5: Reward calm behaviours and support voluntary engagement to build emotional resilience.

Brief Description: This module explains how a dog’s breed traits and individual personality influence communication and behaviour.
Detailed Description: Breed tendencies influence energy, sensitivity, social needs, and communication style. This module teaches owners how herding breeds, guardian breeds, retrievers, terriers, scent hounds, and toy breeds differ in their instincts and body language. It also covers how individual temperament—confident, cautious, social, independent—affects communication. Understanding these factors helps owners set realistic expectations and adapt handling appropriately.
Detailed Step 1: Review common behavioural tendencies across breed groups such as herding, guarding, sporting, terrier, and working types.
Detailed Step 2: Observe which traits your dog exhibits—vigilance, high energy, independence, or sensitivity.
Detailed Step 3: Consider temperament differences within breeds, such as bold vs. cautious.
Detailed Step 4: Adjust your handling to your dog’s communication style, energy level, and genetic predispositions.
Detailed Step 5: Use this understanding to set realistic training expectations and reduce frustration.

Module title: Building better communication with your dog
Brief Description: This module teaches how to communicate clearly and build a cooperative training relationship.
Detailed Description: Effective communication creates trust, reduces confusion, and strengthens your relationship. This module teaches timing, tone of voice, reinforcement clarity, cue consistency, and body language awareness. Owners learn how to communicate in ways dogs understand while avoiding mixed messages that lead to ignoring cues or inconsistent behaviour.
Detailed Step 1: Ensure everyone uses the same cue words and reinforcement rules to create predictable communication.
Detailed Step 2: Use simple, clear cues delivered once, avoiding repeating instructions.
Detailed Step 3: Mark and reward behaviours promptly so your dog understands exactly what earned the reinforcement.
Detailed Step 4: Pay attention to your body language—leaning forward, stepping toward, or reaching over can unintentionally pressure or confuse your dog.
Detailed Step 5: Practise short, daily engagement sessions to build a strong communication foundation.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Module title: Preparing mentally and practically for adoption
Brief Description: This module prepares owners for the emotional and practical realities of adopting a rescue or older dog.
Detailed Description: Rescue dogs often come with unknown histories, varied experiences, and unique emotional needs. This module helps you understand what to expect, how to manage your own expectations, and how to prepare your home and mindset for a smoother transition. You'll learn why patience, structure, and empathy are essential and how preparation can significantly reduce early challenges.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by learning about common rescue dog experiences such as previous trauma, inconsistent care, or lack of training.
Detailed Step 2: Prepare your home with safe spaces, gates, and predictable routines to reduce overwhelm.
Detailed Step 3: Set realistic expectations—many dogs take weeks or months to feel secure.
Detailed Step 4: Plan the first weeks with quiet predictability, limiting big outings or overwhelming social interactions.
Detailed Step 5: Commit to patience and empathy, recognising that building trust takes time.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Module title: What to expect during adjustment period
Brief Description: This module explains the stages rescue dogs go through as they adjust to a new home.
Detailed Description: Many rescue dogs follow a common adjustment pattern: the decompression period, the settling-in phase, and the true personality stage. This module teaches what behaviours to expect in each stage, how to support your dog emotionally, and how to prevent overwhelm. Understanding these phases avoids misinterpretation and supports a smoother transition.
Detailed Step 1: Support decompression by providing quiet, minimal pressure, and a predictable environment.
Detailed Step 2: Introduce simple daily routines to help your dog feel safe and understand expectations.
Detailed Step 3: Avoid overwhelming stimuli such as crowded places, long outings, or chaotic play.
Detailed Step 4: Track improvements in behaviour to understand your dog’s pace of adjustment.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module teaches how to build trust with a rescue dog and help them overcome fear or insecurity.
Detailed Description: Rescue dogs often struggle with fear, uncertainty, or past negative experiences. This module teaches how to use positive reinforcement, consent-based interactions, predictable routines, and gentle exposure to help your dog feel safe. You'll learn how to recognise fear signals, avoid pushing too quickly, and build trust through choice and consistency.
Detailed Step 1: Move at your dog’s pace—slow, soft interactions prevent overwhelming them.
Detailed Step 2: Offer choices (approach/retreat) to build confidence and trust.
Detailed Step 3: Reward small moments of bravery like sniffing new objects or approaching people.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid pushing your dog toward feared stimuli, which can worsen fear.
Detailed Step 5: Build predictable routines so your dog learns what to expect each day, reducing anxiety.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module explains how older dogs learn differently than puppies and how to adapt training appropriately.
Detailed Description: Older dogs can absolutely learn, but they may have physical limitations, slower processing, or established habits. This module teaches how to adapt training sessions, modify expectations, choose appropriate rewards, and support physical comfort. Understanding these differences makes training fair and enjoyable for senior or adult rescue dogs.
Detailed Step 1: Observe physical limitations such as joint stiffness or slower movement.
Detailed Step 2: Adjust training pace, allowing more time for processing and response.
Detailed Step 3: Use high-value rewards to increase motivation and engagement.
Detailed Step 4: Keep training sessions short to prevent fatigue.
Detailed Step 5: Celebrate improvements, recognising that progress may come in smaller steps for older dogs.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module covers common behavioural issues seen in rescue dogs and how to address them safely.
Detailed Description: Rescue dogs may show behaviours linked to fear, lack of structure, previous neglect, or survival strategies. This module explains reactivity, resource guarding, escape attempts, shutdown behaviours, and hypervigilance. Owners learn how to manage environments, use positive reinforcement, avoid punishment, and seek professional help when needed.
Detailed Step 1: Identify the specific behaviour (reactivity, guarding, fleeing) and its possible emotional root.
Detailed Step 2: Create a management plan using gates, leashes, or controlled exposures to prevent rehearsing unwanted behaviour.
Detailed Step 3: Reduce environmental triggers and avoid overwhelming situations.
Detailed Step 4: Teach and reinforce alternative behaviours such as checking in, going to a mat, or moving away.
Detailed Step 5: Seek professional support if behaviour worsens or poses safety concerns.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module provides a structured plan for the first month with a rescue or older dog.
Detailed Description: A structured first month helps a rescue dog settle, feel secure, and begin learning. This module provides a weekly guide covering routine building, crate or safe space training, social exposure, basic life skills, and early behaviour prevention. Owners learn how to balance progress with patience and when to adjust the plan based on the dog's comfort level.
Detailed Step 1: Start with a week-by-week structure covering decompression, routine introduction, beginner training, and gradual exposure.
Detailed Step 2: Focus on predictable daily routines such as meals, rest, and toileting.
Detailed Step 3: Introduce gentle training like name recognition, hand targeting, and calmness foundations.
Detailed Step 4: Add safe, distance-based social exposure to new environments and people.
Detailed Step 5: Adjust pace as needed to match your dog’s confidence and emotional stability.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Module title: Preparing mentally and practically for adoption
Brief Description: This module prepares owners for the emotional and practical responsibilities of adopting a rescue or older dog.
Detailed Description: Adopting a rescue or older dog requires realistic expectations, patience, and understanding. This module teaches what to expect emotionally, how to prepare your home, how to set up routines early, and how to support a dog with an unknown history. Owners learn how to create a stable environment, establish trust, and avoid overwhelming the dog during the first days and weeks.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by acknowledging that rescue dogs often need time to decompress and may not reveal their true personality for days or weeks.
Detailed Step 2: Prepare your home using gates, pens, or crates to create a predictable and safe environment.
Detailed Step 3: Plan a calm first week with simple routines, limited visitors, and gentle introductions.
Detailed Step 4: Reduce overwhelming experiences such as busy outings or too much handling early on.
Detailed Step 5: Provide consistent feeding, toileting, and rest routines to help your dog feel secure.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Module title: What to expect during adjustment period
Brief Description: This module explains the “honeymoon period” and behavioural adjustment in rescue dogs.
Detailed Description: Rescue or older dogs often go through a decompression period where behaviour changes as they settle in. This module explains common patterns such as initial shutdown, increased testing of boundaries, reactivity changes, or regression. Owners learn how to support the dog through fear, adjustment, and early trust-building while avoiding common mistakes that prolong stress.
Detailed Step 1: Learn the typical decompression timeline: initial withdrawal, gradual exploration, testing boundaries, and eventual stabilisation.
Detailed Step 2: Expect behaviour to shift as your dog becomes more comfortable, sometimes revealing issues not seen initially.
Detailed Step 3: Avoid overwhelming environments, busy events, or too much freedom early on.
Detailed Step 4: Maintain calm, predictable routines to help your dog feel stable and safe.
Detailed Step 5: Give your dog ample patience and time to adjust emotionally and behaviourally.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module teaches how to build trust with rescue dogs who may have past trauma or fear.
Detailed Description: Many rescue dogs have experienced inconsistent care or stressful situations. This module teaches owners how to build trust through gentle handling, predictable routines, choice-based training, and avoiding force. You’ll learn how to desensitise fearful dogs, how to respect thresholds, and how to use reinforcement to build confidence over time.
Detailed Step 1: Approach your dog slowly and avoid leaning over or reaching abruptly, which can feel threatening.
Detailed Step 2: Provide choice by letting your dog approach you rather than forcing interactions.
Detailed Step 3: Reward any curiosity or voluntary engagement to build positive associations.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid physically pushing, dragging, or flooding fearful dogs with overwhelming stimuli.
Detailed Step 5: Progress slowly by increasing exposure only as your dog shows comfort and confidence.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module explains how older dogs learn differently from puppies and how to adapt training accordingly.
Detailed Description: Older dogs often learn more slowly but more steadily than puppies. This module explains how to modify training sessions for slower processing speeds, physical limitations, and past learning history. You’ll learn how to adapt reinforcement, reduce physical strain, and create achievable training expectations based on age and health.
Detailed Step 1: Use shorter training sessions to match your dog's cognitive processing speed.
Detailed Step 2: Modify physical tasks to avoid strain on joints or muscles.
Detailed Step 3: Use motivating rewards that keep older dogs engaged.
Detailed Step 4: Practise patience and avoid comparing progress to younger dogs.
Detailed Step 5: Adjust training objectives based on your dog's comfort, mobility, and learning history.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module helps owners identify and manage common behavioural challenges in rescue dogs.
Detailed Description: Rescue dogs may come with behaviours such as reactivity, resource guarding, fear of confinement, escape attempts, or sensitivity to handling. This module explains why these behaviours occur, how to manage them safely, and when to seek professional help. Owners learn step-by-step strategies to reduce fear and reactivity while supporting the dog’s emotional needs.
Detailed Step 1: Identify which behaviours your rescue dog struggles with most—reactivity, guarding, fear, or escape behaviours.
Detailed Step 2: Use management tools such as gates, leashes, and crates to keep everyone safe.
Detailed Step 3: Avoid punishment or harsh corrections, which can worsen fear-based behaviours.
Detailed Step 4: Focus on creating safety and predictability through structure and routine.
Detailed Step 5: Seek help from a trainer or behaviourist if behaviours escalate or become unsafe.

Category title: Adopting a Rescue or Older Dog
Brief Description: This module provides a structured 30-day plan for newly adopted dogs.
Detailed Description: A strong first month sets the foundation for long-term behaviour and trust. This module provides a simple weekly plan including routine building, crate or pen training, early socialisation, basic manners, and introductions to exercise. Owners learn how to progress gradually, track changes, and avoid pushing the dog too quickly during the adjustment period.
Detailed Step 1: Prioritise routine above complex training to build stability.
Detailed Step 2: Track progress weekly to recognise wins and detect patterns.
Detailed Step 3: Adjust the pace based on your dog's confidence and comfort—never rush the process.

Brief Description: This module teaches your dog to pay attention on leash instead of pulling or scanning.
Detailed Description: Leash attention is the foundation for all loose-leash walking. Dogs must learn that checking in with their handler is rewarding, and that attention prevents pulling. This module explains how to build eye contact, engagement, and focus before ever walking in distracting places. Teaching attention early prevents leash frustration and prepares the dog for calm walking later.
Detailed Step 1: Begin in a quiet area and reward your dog whenever they look at you, even briefly.
Detailed Step 2: Practise indoors and in the yard to strengthen the behaviour without distractions.
Detailed Step 3: Gradually introduce low-level distractions such as mild outdoor noises.
Detailed Step 4: Use a marker (“Yes!”) every time your dog offers voluntary eye contact.
Detailed Step 5: Keep sessions short and upbeat to build engagement before real walks.

Brief Description: This module teaches fun games that encourage your dog to stay mentally connected during walks.
Detailed Description: Dogs who stay engaged are far less likely to pull. This module introduces simple games like hand-targets, reward-following, and quick attention cues. Owners learn how to switch between fun engagement and calm walking, building reliability even around distractions. These games reduce pulling by teaching your dog that staying near you is rewarding and enjoyable.
Detailed Step 1: Teach your dog to touch your hand with their nose, using the behaviour to redirect them.
Detailed Step 2: Practise fast attention cues (“Look!”) to help your dog refocus when excited.
Detailed Step 3: Add movement-based games such as turning away, walking backward, or stepping sideways.
Detailed Step 4: Reward your dog for choosing to walk near you, reinforcing voluntary heel-zone walking.
Detailed Step 5: Use engagement games before entering high-distraction areas to prime focus.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners the difference between relaxed loose leash walking and formal heel.
Detailed Description: Loose leash walking and heel are different skills. Loose leash walking allows sniffing and exploring as long as the leash stays slack, while heel is structured and precise. This module explains how to teach both, when to use them, and how to avoid confusing the dog. Owners learn how to switch between relaxed walking and focused heel in real-world situations.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by teaching loose leash walking: reward your dog whenever the leash is slack and they remain within your general walking zone.
Detailed Step 2: Teach heel separately by rewarding your dog for staying beside your left or right leg with attention.
Detailed Step 3: Use distinct cues such as “Let’s go” for loose walking and “Heel” for structured walking.
Detailed Step 4: Practise switching between the two modes in low-distraction environments.
Detailed Step 5: Reinforce heavily when your dog makes correct choices, especially early in training.

Brief Description: This module teaches impulse control and restarts during leash walking.
Detailed Description: Teaching stop/go cues prevents pulling, rushing, or forging ahead. This module explains how to teach the dog to pause calmly when the handler stops, and to restart walking only when cued. These cues create structure, prevent leash tension, and reduce confusion during real-world walks.
Detailed Step 1: Stop walking abruptly and wait for your dog to pause or look back; mark and reward the moment they stop tension.
Detailed Step 2: Reward stillness so your dog understands that stopping leads to calm behaviour.
Detailed Step 3: Introduce “Let’s go” as the restart cue and reward your dog for moving off with you.
Detailed Step 4: Practise indoors or in your yard before attempting these cues on real walks.
Detailed Step 5: Add mild distractions gradually to improve reliability.

Brief Description: This module teaches dogs how to stay calm and responsive near distractions.
Detailed Description: Distractions such as dogs, people, birds, or smells can cause pulling or overstimulation. This module teaches distance management, focus recovery, and reward strategies. Owners learn how to read their dog’s arousal levels, create distance when needed, and teach alternative behaviours to replace pulling or lunging.
Detailed Step 1: Increase distance from distractions to keep your dog below their threshold.
Detailed Step 2: Use focus cues such as name recognition or hand targets to reconnect.
Detailed Step 3: Reward calm decisions such as glancing at distractions but choosing to stay near you.
Detailed Step 4: Redirect early when your dog first notices a distraction, before arousal spikes.
Detailed Step 5: Practise predictable setups like observing distractions from a distance to build success.

Brief Description: This module teaches safe and effective ways to manage reactive behaviour on leash.
Detailed Description: Reactivity often stems from fear, excitement, frustration, or lack of socialisation. This module explains why dogs react, how to avoid triggers, create space, use desensitisation, and build alternative behaviours. Owners learn management techniques to stay safe and help their dog develop calmer emotional responses over time.
Detailed Step 1: Identify your dog’s reactivity triggers such as dogs, vehicles, or fast movement.
Detailed Step 2: Increase distance as soon as you spot the trigger to avoid going over threshold.
Detailed Step 3: Keep the leash loose and avoid pulling, which increases tension and reactivity.
Detailed Step 4: Reward calm glances and turning away from triggers.
Detailed Step 5: Seek professional help for severe or unpredictable reactivity.

Module title: Step-by-step progression to calm, confident walks
Brief Description: This module provides a structured program that builds loose leash walking skill over time.
Detailed Description: This final module combines all leash-walking skills into a clear progression. Owners learn how to begin in low-distraction environments, introduce new challenges gradually, build endurance, and proof behaviours. The module also explains how to troubleshoot setbacks and maintain consistency for long-term success.
Detailed Step 1: Begin practising in your home, where distractions are minimal and success is easy to achieve.
