Detailed Step 2: Move to the yard once your dog can maintain attention indoors.
Detailed Step 3: Add short and quiet outdoor walks, rewarding frequently for slack-leash walking.
Detailed Step 4: Introduce mild distractions such as passing people or distant dogs.
Detailed Step 5: Gradually increase distance, duration, and complexity while maintaining engagement and calm behaviour.

Brief Description: This module explains the root causes behind common behaviour issues so owners can address them effectively.
Detailed Description: Dogs rarely misbehave out of defiance; their behaviours always have a cause. This module explains how unmet needs, stress, fear, lack of training, genetics, or confusion drive unwanted behaviours. Understanding the “why” behind behaviour helps owners choose training solutions that are fair, humane, and effective.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by identifying the cause behind each behaviour—fear, boredom, overexcitement, confusion, or reinforcement history.
Detailed Step 2: Observe the context to determine when and why the behaviour occurs.
Detailed Step 3: Identify triggers such as visitors, noises, other dogs, or sudden changes.
Detailed Step 4: Adjust the environment to reduce stress or prevent rehearsal of the unwanted behaviour.
Detailed Step 5: Choose a training plan based on the root cause, not just the behaviour itself.

Module title: Barking, digging, chewing, and biting — root causes
Brief Description: This module helps owners break down the underlying causes of the most common problem behaviours.
Detailed Description: Problem behaviours such as barking, digging, chewing, and biting usually come from unmet needs, excess energy, stress, or lack of boundaries. This module explains the science behind each behaviour and teaches owners how to apply targeted training strategies. Instead of punishing symptoms, owners learn to meet their dog’s needs and guide them toward appropriate alternatives.
Detailed Step 1: Identify which underlying need—exercise, mental stimulation, emotional regulation, or comfort—is missing.
Detailed Step 2: Meet that need first before addressing the behaviour directly.
Detailed Step 3: Provide appropriate alternatives such as chew toys, digging boxes, or quiet resting areas.
Detailed Step 4: Use structured training sessions to build coping skills and impulse control.
Detailed Step 5: Prevent rehearsal by supervising or managing the environment effectively.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to prevent door-dashing and teach safe boundary behaviour.
Detailed Description: Door dashing can be dangerous. This module shows owners how to teach their dog to wait calmly at thresholds, respond to release cues, and follow structured routines around doors. Owners learn safe management, leash control, and boundary-setting to prevent escape attempts and build impulse control.
Detailed Step 1: Teach your dog to wait at doors by using a hand signal or verbal cue.
Detailed Step 2: Increase distance from the door so your dog learns not to rush forward.
Detailed Step 3: Add mild distractions like opening the door slightly or stepping away.
Detailed Step 4: Reward calm behaviour when your dog remains behind the boundary.
Detailed Step 5: Use the same rules for every door to avoid confusion and build consistency.

Brief Description: This module teaches safe strategies for preventing and reducing resource guarding.
Detailed Description: Resource guarding is a natural behaviour but can become dangerous if not addressed. This module teaches owners how to prevent guarding early, how to trade safely, how to teach drop and leave-it, and how to build positive associations around people approaching food or toys. Owners also learn management strategies and red flags requiring professional help.
Detailed Step 1: Avoid grabbing items from your dog, which increases guarding instincts.
Detailed Step 2: Teach a gentle trade by offering a high-value treat for the item your dog has.
Detailed Step 3: Practise “Drop it” using positive reinforcement to build reliability.
Detailed Step 4: Pair your approach to your dog’s food or toy with rewards so your presence predicts good things.
Detailed Step 5: Manage the environment by removing high-value items when unsupervised.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to safely manage and improve leash reactivity or fear-based aggression.
Detailed Description: Reactivity stems from fear, frustration, or lack of socialisation, not dominance. This module teaches owners how to identify triggers, create safe distance, use counterconditioning, and avoid mistakes that make reactivity worse. You'll learn how to build alternative behaviours, reduce emotional arousal, and support your dog in challenging environments.
Detailed Step 1: Identify the triggers that cause your dog to react—people, dogs, noises, or sudden movement.
Detailed Step 2: Increase distance immediately when your dog notices the trigger, keeping them below threshold.
Detailed Step 3: Use counterconditioning by pairing the trigger with high-value rewards at a safe distance.
Detailed Step 4: Train alternative behaviours such as looking at you, hand targets, or moving away.
Detailed Step 5: Avoid rehearsal of reactive episodes, which strengthens the unwanted behaviour.

Module title: Creating a management and training plan
Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to combine management and training into a long-term plan.
Detailed Description: Management prevents unwanted behaviours from being practised, while training teaches new skills. This module helps owners create balanced plans that address triggers, prevent failure, and promote progress. Owners learn how to track steps, adjust intensity, and maintain consistency for long-term success.
Detailed Step 1: Identify which behaviours need immediate management versus long-term training.
Detailed Step 2: Set a clear structure for what will be managed (prevented) and what will be trained (taught).
Detailed Step 3: Create safe setups that allow the dog to practise correct behaviours.
Detailed Step 4: Track progress weekly to see patterns and improvements.
Detailed Step 5: Adjust training plans based on your dog’s progress and emotional state.

Brief Description: This module teaches structured socialization to prevent fear, reactivity, and anxiety later in life.
Detailed Description: Early socialization shapes how dogs respond to the world throughout their entire life. This module explains how to safely expose puppies to people, dogs, environments, sounds, textures, and handling while avoiding overwhelming them. Owners learn how to build positive associations, create safe experiences, and prevent fear-based behaviours from emerging later.
Detailed Step 1: Use a well-planned socialization checklist to expose your puppy to a variety of safe experiences.
Detailed Step 2: Begin exposure at a distance or intensity your puppy can handle comfortably.
Detailed Step 3: Pair each new experience with treats, play, or encouragement to build positive associations.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid overwhelming your puppy by stopping exposure if signs of stress appear.
Detailed Step 5: Track experiences to ensure balanced exposure across people, animals, environments, and sounds.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to support dogs during normal developmental fear periods.
Detailed Description: Fear periods are natural stages where puppies suddenly become wary of things they previously accepted. This module helps owners understand why these periods occur and how to respond calmly and supportively. Owners learn what to avoid, how to build confidence, and how to prevent long-term fear or reactivity from developing.
Detailed Step 1: Stay calm when your dog shows sudden fear; avoid reacting dramatically.
Detailed Step 2: Reduce exposure intensity by creating space or lowering difficulty.
Detailed Step 3: Pair previously safe stimuli with treats or gentle praise.
Detailed Step 4: Avoid pushing or forcing your dog toward the trigger.
Detailed Step 5: Revisit the situation later when your dog is more relaxed and confident.

Brief Description: This module teaches exercises and training strategies that build emotional resilience in dogs.
Detailed Description: Resilience helps dogs recover quickly from stress and adapt to new situations confidently. This module covers confidence-building games, controlled exposure exercises, problem-solving activities, and independence training. Owners learn how predictable routines, gentle challenges, and choice-based interactions strengthen resilience and prevent anxiety or reactivity.
Detailed Step 1: Play confidence-building games like wobble boards, step-on platforms, and novelty-object exploration.
Detailed Step 2: Offer small challenges that encourage problem-solving without overwhelming your dog.
Detailed Step 3: Allow your dog to choose whether to engage rather than forcing participation.
Detailed Step 4: Reinforce brave behaviour such as approaching new objects or trying new movements.
Detailed Step 5: Increase challenge difficulty slowly to keep experiences positive.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to introduce dogs to new situations safely and positively.
Detailed Description: New experiences help dogs become adaptable, confident, and calm adults. This module explains how to introduce new environments, noises, surfaces, and objects safely. Owners learn how to manage intensity, use distance effectively, and build trust while avoiding fear-based reactions or overstimulation.
Detailed Step 1: Begin new experiences at a distance or intensity that your dog finds comfortable.
Detailed Step 2: Pair exposure with treats, encouragement, or play to build positive emotional associations.
Detailed Step 3: Increase exposure gradually, allowing your dog time to observe and process.
Detailed Step 4: Watch for stress signals such as lip licking or avoidance to know when to pause.
Detailed Step 5: Keep sessions short and end on a positive note to build confidence.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to create calm behaviour around exciting or stressful triggers.
Detailed Description: Calmness is a trained skill, not a personality trait. This module teaches techniques like pattern games, mat training, distance management, and calm reinforcement. Owners learn how to help their dog remain composed around triggers such as visitors, noisy environments, or other dogs, preventing reactivity or overstimulation from developing.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by increasing distance from triggers so your dog can stay calm and think clearly.
Detailed Step 2: Reward calm behaviours such as sitting, looking away, or lying down.
Detailed Step 3: Use pattern games to give your dog predictable cues that reduce anxiety.
Detailed Step 4: Practise calm behaviour on a mat to build a reliable relaxation routine.
Detailed Step 5: Gradually introduce more challenging triggers while maintaining calm responses.

Brief Description: This module helps owners identify early signs of stress before behaviour escalates.
Detailed Description: Dogs communicate stress long before they bark, growl, or react. This module teaches owners how to recognise subtle signs like lip licking, yawning, tremors, pacing, and avoidance. Understanding these early signals prevents overwhelm and allows owners to adjust situations before fear or frustration builds.
Detailed Step 1: Learn common stress indicators such as panting when not hot, pacing, pinned ears, stiff posture, or avoiding eye contact.
Detailed Step 2: Observe your dog throughout normal routines to understand their baseline behaviour.
Detailed Step 3: Identify triggers that repeatedly cause stress and note patterns.
Detailed Step 4: Adjust the environment by reducing noise, increasing distance, or lowering stimulation.
Detailed Step 5: Support calm behaviour with rewards, movement breaks, or rest depending on the situation.

Module title: Preparing for travel (car, air, and other transport)
Brief Description: This module helps owners teach dogs to travel comfortably and safely.
Detailed Description: Travel can be stressful for dogs unfamiliar with motion, confinement, or new environments. This module explains how to build positive associations with carriers, cars, crates, and travel routines. It covers safety equipment, desensitisation steps, preparation for long trips, and managing anxiety in transit.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by letting your dog explore the stationary car or travel crate with treats and praise.
Detailed Step 2: Add very short rides once your dog is comfortable entering.
Detailed Step 3: Pair every travel experience with rewards to build positive emotional associations.
Detailed Step 4: Practise time inside a travel crate or carrier to reduce fear of confinement.
Detailed Step 5: Prepare essential travel gear—seatbelts, harnesses, water, cooling mats, or calming aids.

Module title: Helping your dog adjust to new environments
Brief Description: This module teaches dogs how to cope calmly with unfamiliar places, smells, and routines.
Detailed Description: New environments can overwhelm dogs due to novel scents, surfaces, and sounds. This module teaches gradual exposure, confidence-building strategies, and how to avoid forcing interaction. Owners learn how to guide dogs through new areas using calm reinforcement, allowing them to acclimate at their own pace.
Detailed Step 1: Begin new exposures at a comfortable distance or in a calm corner of the environment.
Detailed Step 2: Allow your dog to explore voluntarily, avoiding pulling or pressuring them.
Detailed Step 3: Pair exploration with treats and praise to foster confidence.
Detailed Step 4: Watch for stress cues to know when to slow down or create distance.
Detailed Step 5: Gradually increase exposure to new areas, surfaces, and sounds as your dog becomes more confident.

Module title: What to do if your dog can’t travel with you
Brief Description: This module helps owners prepare dogs for staying with a sitter, boarding facility, or family member.
Detailed Description: When dogs cannot accompany their owners, preparation helps reduce stress and separation difficulty. This module explains how to choose appropriate care, prepare your dog with trial visits, supply comfort items, and maintain routines. Owners learn how to ensure their dog feels safe and supported even when away from their primary caregiver.
Detailed Step 1: Select a sitter or boarding facility that aligns with your dog’s temperament, needs, and social comfort.
Detailed Step 2: Schedule short trial visits so your dog can build familiarity.
Detailed Step 3: Pack items that smell like home such as blankets, toys, or worn clothing.
Detailed Step 4: Maintain your dog’s feeding schedule to promote stability.
Detailed Step 5: Provide written instructions covering routines, medications, preferences, and behavioural notes.

Brief Description: This module helps dogs stay calm during changes in schedule, environment, or routine.
Detailed Description: Dogs thrive on predictability, so major changes can trigger stress or confusion. This module teaches owners how to maintain stability during life transitions such as moving homes, schedule changes, new pets, or travel. Techniques include gradual adjustments, calmness training, enrichment, and reassurance.
Detailed Step 1: Introduce schedule or environment changes gradually whenever possible.
Detailed Step 2: Keep core routines—feeding, walks, sleep—as consistent as possible.
Detailed Step 3: Use enrichment such as puzzle feeders or sniffing games to reduce stress.
Detailed Step 4: Reward calm behaviour and provide reassurance during transitions.
Detailed Step 5: Avoid exposing your dog to excessive stimulation during periods of change.

Module title: What changes during the teenage phase
Brief Description: This module explains the major behavioural and hormonal changes that occur during adolescence.
Detailed Description: During adolescence, dogs experience hormonal shifts that affect impulse control, confidence, fear responses, and energy levels. This module explains why training may regress, how to support emotional development, and why patience is essential. Understanding this phase prevents frustration and helps owners manage temporary behavioural challenges effectively.
Detailed Step 1: Learn how hormones affect behaviour, including increased impulsivity and fluctuating confidence.
Detailed Step 2: Expect temporary regressions in training—even well-trained dogs may forget cues.
Detailed Step 3: Support calmness with structured exercise, enrichment, and rest.
Detailed Step 4: Increase structure in routines to provide predictability during hormonal shifts.
Detailed Step 5: Practise patience and avoid punishment, recognising that adolescence is a normal developmental stage.

Brief Description: This module teaches strategies for dealing with increased impulsivity in adolescent dogs.
Detailed Description: Adolescent dogs often push boundaries, ignore cues, and display increased curiosity. This module teaches impulse-control exercises, consistency in rules, appropriate outlets for energy, and how to prevent the dog from practising unwanted behaviours. Owners learn how to guide teens into calmer, more thoughtful behaviour.
Detailed Step 1: Reinforce household rules consistently to prevent teenage boundary-pushing.
Detailed Step 2: Practise impulse-control exercises such as wait, settle, and leave-it.
Detailed Step 3: Provide structured outlets like training sessions, scent work, and controlled play.
Detailed Step 4: Use clear and consistent cues to reduce confusion.
Detailed Step 5: Prevent unwanted behaviours by supervising and managing the environment.

Brief Description: This module helps owners understand and manage normal training regressions in adolescents.
Detailed Description: Training regressions are normal as dogs experience hormonal and developmental changes that temporarily affect focus. This module explains why regressions happen and how to respond effectively using patience, consistency, and returning to easier versions of skills. Owners learn how to maintain progress without frustration.
Detailed Step 1: Expect your dog to forget cues or struggle with focus—even if previously reliable.
Detailed Step 2: Lower training difficulty temporarily by working in low-distraction areas.
Detailed Step 3: Reinforce foundation skills such as name recognition and calmness.
Detailed Step 4: Stay consistent with rules and routines to provide structure.
Detailed Step 5: Track progress to see improvements over time.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to channel adolescent energy into healthy, productive outlets.
Detailed Description: Adolescent dogs have high energy and strong drive, which can lead to destructive behaviour if not directed properly. This module covers safe physical exercise, mental stimulation, enrichment activities, and breed-specific outlets that reduce boredom and overstimulation. Balanced outlets improve behaviour dramatically.
Detailed Step 1: Increase structured physical exercise appropriate for the dog's breed and age.
Detailed Step 2: Use mental enrichment tools like puzzles, scent work, and food-based activities.
Detailed Step 3: Incorporate training games that build focus and engagement.
Detailed Step 4: Allow natural behaviours like sniffing or chewing using safe outlets.
Detailed Step 5: Rotate activities throughout the week to prevent boredom.

Brief Description: This module explains hormone-driven behaviours and how to manage them safely and calmly.
Detailed Description: Hormones can cause increased arousal, humping, marking, and mounting during adolescence. This module teaches owners how to reduce these behaviours using redirection, management, increased rest, and appropriate outlets. It also covers when behaviours are normal, when they indicate stress, and how to prevent reinforcement.
Detailed Step 1: Identify arousal-based behaviours such as humping or mounting as signals of stress, excitement, or hormonal drive.
Detailed Step 2: Redirect your dog to an appropriate behaviour such as a chew toy, sit, or mat.
Detailed Step 3: Avoid accidentally reinforcing the behaviour by laughing, touching, or pushing.
Detailed Step 4: Provide calmness outlets like sniff walks, enrichment, or crate rest.
Detailed Step 5: Increase rest and reduce overstimulation, especially after high-energy events.

Ideal Stage of Life: All ages (especially rescues or dogs with hearing loss)
Brief Description: This module teaches how to communicate using visual signals instead of verbal cues.
Detailed Description: Dogs who are deaf or hearing-impaired rely heavily on visual cues, body language, and touch-based communication. This module explains how to build a strong communication system using clear hand signals, eye contact, body movement, and predictable patterns. Owners learn how to avoid startle responses and how to reward visual attention to build engagement.
Detailed Step 1: Select clear, distinct hand signals for each behaviour you plan to teach.
Detailed Step 2: Teach eye contact as a foundation, rewarding your dog for voluntarily checking in visually.
Detailed Step 3: Use consistent body language—slow movements, calm posture, and intentional gestures.
Detailed Step 4: Practise predictable interaction patterns so your dog can anticipate cues through routine.
Detailed Step 5: Reward generously for successful responses to visual signals to reinforce learning.

Brief Description: This module teaches dogs to look at their owner reliably, even without verbal cues.
Detailed Description: Visual attention is the foundation of all deaf dog communication. This module explains how to teach focus using rewards, gentle touch cues, and reinforcement of voluntary check-ins. Owners learn how to build reliable eye contact that transitions smoothly into structured training sessions.
Detailed Step 1: Begin by rewarding any voluntary eye contact, using a thumbs-up marker to confirm correct behaviour.
Detailed Step 2: Add a hand signal such as pointing to your eyes.
Detailed Step 3: Fade food lures gradually so your dog relies on the visual cue alone.
Detailed Step 4: Practise eye contact in mildly distracting environments to strengthen reliability.
Detailed Step 5: Build duration by increasing the length of eye contact before delivering the reward.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to use visual markers and consistent hand cues effectively.
Detailed Description: Deaf dogs cannot hear verbal markers, so visual markers such as a thumbs-up, flash of fingers, or gentle touch markers are used instead. This module explains how to condition a visual marker, choose hand cues, avoid cue clutter, and maintain clarity. Owners learn how to pair markers with rewards in a way that maintains precise timing.
Detailed Step 1: Choose a simple visual marker—commonly a thumbs-up gesture—that will indicate correct behaviour.
Detailed Step 2: Use the marker consistently with all behaviours to build reliable understanding.
Detailed Step 3: Practise timing drills by marking simple behaviours like sits or touches.
Detailed Step 4: Add clear, distinct hand cues slowly to avoid overwhelming your dog.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to keep deaf dogs safe and confident at home and outdoors.
Detailed Description: Deaf dogs can be easily startled and may not respond to danger cues like cars or other dogs. This module explains safe leash handling, secure environments, touch-based attention cues, and confidence-building exercises. Owners learn how to reduce startle responses, teach safe recall alternatives, and prevent fear-related behaviours.
Detailed Step 1: Use a secure leash or harness to prevent accidental escapes, especially outdoors.
Detailed Step 2: Teach a gentle tap or touch cue to get your dog's attention without startling them.
Detailed Step 3: Reduce startle responses by pairing touch with predictable patterns and rewards.
Detailed Step 4: Build confidence with exposure to new environments at the dog's pace.
Detailed Step 5: Practise safety routines such as checking in before transitions or walking near roads.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to modify training and care for senior dogs.
Detailed Description: Senior dogs experience cognitive, sensory, and physical changes that affect training and daily life. This module helps owners understand how aging affects mobility, learning speed, and comfort. It explains how to adjust goals, routines, and training approaches to suit older dogs while maintaining engagement and quality of life.
Detailed Step 1: Reduce the intensity of training and avoid high-impact physical tasks.
Detailed Step 2: Use shorter training sessions to match slower processing speeds.
Detailed Step 3: Adapt training goals to reflect your dog's physical and cognitive comfort.
Detailed Step 4: Provide comfort through warm bedding, softer surfaces, and supportive equipment.
Detailed Step 5: Support mobility with ramps, traction mats, and gentle movement exercises.

Brief Description: This module teaches strategies to support brain health and mobility in older dogs.
Detailed Description: As dogs age, they may experience cognitive decline and reduced mobility. This module covers enrichment for brain health, low-impact exercises, pain management awareness, and gentle physical engagement to maintain quality of life. Owners learn how to support their dog’s aging body through thoughtful routines and activities.
Detailed Step 1: Incorporate brain games such as scent work, puzzle feeders, and simple training tasks.
Detailed Step 2: Use low-impact exercise options like slow walks or swimming.
Detailed Step 3: Watch for signs of pain such as limping, hesitation, or stiffness.
Detailed Step 4: Encourage gentle movement including stretching or slow navigation over soft obstacles.
Detailed Step 5: Maintain predictable routines to reduce stress and support cognitive function.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to keep senior dogs mentally engaged and physically comfortable.
Detailed Description: Older dogs benefit from continued engagement, gentle enrichment, and comfortable living environments. This module explains how to maintain mental stimulation without overwhelming the dog, how to support joints and mobility, and how to adapt daily routines. Owners learn to recognise their dog’s limits while keeping life enjoyable and fulfilling.
Detailed Step 1: Provide soft, supportive bedding that reduces pressure on joints.
Detailed Step 2: Use gentle enrichment activities that engage the mind without demanding strenuous physical effort.
Detailed Step 3: Adapt the home environment with ramps, rugs, or easily accessible resting areas.
Detailed Step 4: Monitor your dog for signs of fatigue or discomfort during activities.
Detailed Step 5: Keep training sessions short and encouraging, focusing on comfort and enjoyment.

Brief Description: This module teaches how to build a strong, trusting lifelong relationship with your dog.
Detailed Description: A deep bond is the foundation of every successful training journey. This module explains how trust, predictability, positive reinforcement, shared experiences, and consistent communication create a solid emotional connection. Owners learn how to meet their dog’s emotional needs, build relationship-based training habits, and prevent misunderstandings or conflict.
Detailed Step 1: Build trust by meeting your dog's needs consistently—food, rest, exercise, and safety.
Detailed Step 2: Use positive reinforcement to strengthen cooperative behaviour and mutual confidence.
Detailed Step 3: Share daily experiences like gentle walks, training sessions, and calm downtime.
Detailed Step 4: Practise clear communication through body language, cues, and predictable routines.
Detailed Step 5: Maintain consistency so your dog knows what to expect, reducing stress and confusion.

Module title: Setting your dog up for success
Brief Description: This module helps owners structure their environment and routines to support good behaviour.
Detailed Description: Success in training depends on management, preparation, and proactive planning. This module teaches owners how to structure routines, prevent mistakes, adjust environments, and build habits that help the dog thrive. Topics include enrichment scheduling, exercise balance, rest times, and realistic goal-setting.
Detailed Step 1: Remove tempting or unsafe items before training and ensure the environment supports good choices.
Detailed Step 2: Build predictable routines that give your dog stability and reduce anxiety.
Detailed Step 3: Offer structured enrichment to prevent boredom or frustration.
Detailed Step 4: Reward your dog for making correct choices to reinforce strong habits.
Detailed Step 5: Track progress to identify patterns and adjust training goals accordingly.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how their mindset and emotions affect their dog’s behaviour.
Detailed Description: Dogs are highly sensitive to human emotions, tone, and energy. This module explains how stress, frustration, and inconsistency from the owner can influence training outcomes and behavioural responses. Owners learn how to maintain calmness, regulate emotions, practise patience, and create a positive training atmosphere that supports learning.
Detailed Step 1: Practise patience during training, remembering that learning takes time.
Detailed Step 2: Stay calm and regulate your emotions so your dog remains relaxed and focused.
Detailed Step 3: Avoid training when frustrated, as dogs easily pick up on tension.
Detailed Step 4: Use breaks whenever needed to reset both yourself and your dog.
Detailed Step 5: Reflect on how your mood affects your dog and make adjustments to maintain positivity.

Brief Description: This module provides fun, mentally stimulating games that strengthen the bond and reduce behaviour problems.
Detailed Description: Enrichment prevents boredom, stress, and destructive behaviour. This module provides a variety of games including scent work, puzzle feeders, tug, fetch, hide-and-seek, and problem-solving challenges. Owners learn how to choose activities that match their dog’s personality and energy levels, offering mental and physical outlets that enhance wellbeing.
Detailed Step 1: Choose games that suit your dog’s temperament—high-energy dogs may enjoy tug or fetch, while thoughtful dogs may prefer puzzles.
Detailed Step 2: Rotate activities weekly to maintain novelty and engagement.
Detailed Step 3: Add difficulty gradually to keep your dog challenged but not overwhelmed.
Detailed Step 4: Supervise play sessions to ensure safety, especially with high-arousal games.
Detailed Step 5: End games on a positive note, reinforcing calmness and cooperation.

Brief Description: This module teaches owners how to continue progressing after foundational training is complete.
Detailed Description: Training is a lifelong journey. This module helps owners plan ongoing learning, advanced obedience, sports, trick training, and enrichment-based skills. It covers how to set long-term goals, track achievements, rotate skills, and keep training fun and rewarding as the dog matures. Owners learn how to maintain reliability and prevent regression over time.
Detailed Step 1: Set long-term training goals such as improved recall, off-leash reliability, or learning new tricks.
Detailed Step 2: Build a roadmap of skills to practise and refine each month.
Detailed Step 3: Schedule weekly training sessions to maintain consistency.
Detailed Step 4: Add advanced challenges gradually such as distractions, distance, and duration.
Detailed Step 5: Maintain variety so training remains rewarding and engaging for both you and your dog.
